step: Expect the compost to heat up.
Decide whether to add slow-rotting items.
Be cautious about adding weeds to your compost pile.
Keep animal waste out of your compost bin.
Don't add compostable containers to your home compost bin.
steps:
```pddl
(:action manage_resource
    :parameters (?actor - agent ?resource - object ?location - location ?tool - object)
    :precondition (and 
                    (available ?actor)
                    (or (in_inventory ?actor ?resource)
                        (at ?resource ?location))
                    (or (open ?location)
                        (empty ?location))
                    (not (managed ?resource ?location)))
    :effect (and 
              (managed ?resource ?location)
              (not (in_inventory ?actor ?resource))))

(:action lay
  :parameters (?entity - agent ?resource - object ?location - location)
  :precondition (and 
                  (available ?entity) 
                  (has ?entity ?resource) 
                  (at ?entity ?location)
                  (not (organized ?resource)) 
                  (state ?location neutral))
  :effect (and 
            (organized ?resource) 
            (not (has ?entity ?resource))))

(:action wash
    :parameters (?entity - agent ?item - object ?location - location)
    :precondition (and 
        (at ?entity ?location) 
        (not (processed ?item))
        (or 
            (inventory ?entity ?item)
            (location ?item in_waste_basket)
            (moisture ?item dry)
            (mixed ?item ?entity)
        )
    )
    :effect (and 
        (processed ?item)
        (or 
            (clean ?item)
            (sealed ?item)
            (moisture ?item wet)
            (knowledge ?entity selected)
            (location ?item in_tumbler)
        )))

(:action compost
  :parameters (?agent - agent ?item - compostable ?from - location ?to - location)
  :precondition (and (at ?agent ?from) (location ?item ?from))
  :effect (and (location ?item ?to)))
```

similar_task.task: How to Use Your Home Built Tumble Composter to Create Rich Compost
step: Choose a warm sunny spot to put the tumbler.
Save your vegetable kitchen scraps to add to the tumbler, avoid adding the seeds of vegetables (see tips).
Adding grass clippings and other non-woody garden waste is essential (see tips).
The contents of the composter need to be moist but not wet.
When adding water, use well water or water that has allowed to sit overnight so chlorine can evaporate.
Tumble your composter at least once a week.
In a composter that is working well, the contents should feel warm to the touch.
If your composter is smelly, add a handful of garden lime or dolomite.
Don't overfill the tumbler - try to only fill 2/3's to 3/4's full at anytime.
Depending on how well you balance the moisture level in the tumbler, you will get 2 or 3 loads of rich compost a season.
steps_predictions: add-edge grass clippings and other non-woody garden waste

Continue to alternate layers of carbon-rich and nitrogen-rich material.
Spray the organic material with water.
Keep the bin in the sun.
Turn the compost once a week.
Wait two months.

similar_task.task: How to Find Free Compost Ingredients
step: Ask your local coffee shop if they throw out used coffee grinds.
Inquire with local lumberyards and home improvement stores for free sawdust.
Collect newspapers.
Contact local dairies, feedlots, or cattle operations for composted cow manure.
Call a local food processing plant to inquire if they have any left over organic material.
Visit your local zoo and ask about retrieving compost from the exhibit animals.
Place cardboard over a bed of worms to create worm castings and heavily nutritious composting materials.
Visit Christmas tree lots for mulched trees; many cities and communities recycle Christmas trees, so mulch might be available from this seasonal source.
Contact your city government.
Be neighborly.
Wood Ash is also an excellent soil amendment.

nl_step:
**Task**: How to Compost

**Steps in Natural Language**:
1. **Transfer** your compostable materials to the compost bin using a shovel or trowel.
2. **Arrange** the compostable items neatly inside the compost bin to ensure proper decomposition.
3. **Clean** any compostable items by rinsing them under water before adding them to the bin.
4. **Move** the compostable materials from the collection area to the compost pile to begin the composting process.

step: Use aerated compost tea quickly, preferably within 4 to 6 hours of removing it from the brewer, because it contains living organisms.
Keep the compost tea cool, away from sunlight, and in an open container to prolong the useful life of the tea.
Spray compost tea onto plants covering the leaves thoroughly with a fine mist.
Pour compost tea directly into the soil.
Use compost tea either full strength or in a 1:1 mix with equal amounts of tea and water for indoor and garden plants.
Mix compost tea in a 1:3 part tea to water mixture to cover large areas including lawns.
Use a soil drench and foliar spray application to minimize transplant shock immediately before and after moving plants.
Spray compost tea on foliage at the first sign of symptoms of foliar diseases, such as black spot or powdery mildew.
task: How to Use Aerated Compost Tea
steps:
```pddl
(:action manage_resource
    :parameters (?actor - agent ?resource - object ?location - location ?tool - object)
    :precondition (and 
                    (available ?actor)
                    (or (in_inventory ?actor ?resource)
                        (at ?resource ?location))
                    (or (open ?location)
                        (empty ?location))
                    (not (managed ?resource ?location)))
    :effect (and 
              (managed ?resource ?location)
              (not (in_inventory ?actor ?resource))))

(:action lay
  :parameters (?entity - agent ?resource - object ?location - location)
  :precondition (and 
                  (available ?entity) 
                  (has ?entity ?resource) 
                  (at ?entity ?location)
                  (not (organized ?resource)) 
                  (state ?location neutral))
  :effect (and 
            (organized ?resource) 
            (not (has ?entity ?resource))))

(:action wash
    :parameters (?entity - agent ?item - object ?location - location)
    :precondition (and 
        (at ?entity ?location) 
        (not (processed ?item))
        (or 
            (inventory ?entity ?item)
            (location ?item in_waste_basket)
            (moisture ?item dry)
            (mixed ?item ?entity)
        )
    )
    :effect (and 
        (processed ?item)
        (or 
            (clean ?item)
            (sealed ?item)
            (moisture ?item wet)
            (knowledge ?entity selected)
            (location ?item in_tumbler)
        )))

(:action use
  :parameters (?actor - agent ?resource - object ?location - location)
  :precondition (and 
                  (has ?actor ?resource) 
                  (at ?actor ?location) 
                  (prepared ?resource))
  :effect (and
            (used ?resource) 
            (task_completed ?actor ?location) 
            (not (has ?actor ?resource))))

(:action visit
    :parameters (?npc - agent ?location - location ?item - object)
    :precondition (and (at ?npc ?location) (location_type ?location))
    :effect (and (inventory ?npc ?item) (not (at ?item ?location))))

(:action inquire
  :parameters (?npc - agent ?location - location ?item - object)
  :precondition (and (at ?npc ?location) (source_location ?location))
  :effect (and (inventory ?npc ?item) (not (at ?item ?location))))
```

nl_step:
**Task**: How to Use Aerated Compost Tea

**Steps in Natural Language**:
1. Manage your compost tea resources by ensuring you have the necessary supplies available and properly stored in your designated storage area.
2. Lay out the aerated compost tea in your preparation area, organizing it neatly for easy access during application.
3. Wash any containers or tools you will use with the compost tea to maintain cleanliness and prevent contamination.
4. Use the aerated compost tea by applying it to your plants or garden beds according to the recommended guidelines.
5. Visit your compost tea supplier regularly to replenish your supply and ensure you always have fresh compost tea on hand.
6. Inquire with gardening experts or suppliers to gain additional tips and best practices for effectively using aerated compost tea in your garden.
